content.description:
Make interesting moves up the first steep section to a ledge rest... Climb straight up the wall above following some cracks and interesting (sometimes secret) holds to the top...  

  These routes are close together but all offer something different and really do have there own lines...
content.protection: Regular rack micro cams a plus....
content.location: Left of the arete and right of the low pine tree, climb up to a stance then follow cracks and features up the face to the top...

content.description:
Another fun way to utilize this uverhanging playground... Mostly big moves to good holds with a couple killer crimps near the top... 

  Climb the steep wall between Flight of the Phoenix and the Boy Who Lived... Start with a boulder problem to a ledge rest then a little loose rock to a solid steep wall that could be a bit harder for short climbers... Only a couple good pieces of gear... One at half height and a small nut up hight...
content.protection: Medium cam half way up and a small nut up high... Didnt see anything else yet...
content.location: Between Flight of the Phoenix and The Boy Who Lived...

content.description:
On the left side of the cliff is a lower angle section with fun moderate routes side by side... This is the left most one on this section...  

  Climb up to a ledge left of a low pine tree follow the groove up and a little left to the top... Fun climbing...

Maybe my favorite route here so far... Fun technical climbing on steep rock with good but funky, spicy gear... 

  With some good gear craft this one can be safe but the pro can be very tricky and small... I worked it out on TR first...  Start to the right of the tree near the base of the steep wall and climb up and a little left past funky holds and a pocket or 2 before trending back right and up to the top... Belay from the trees...
content.protection: Purple cam (wierd placement in a pocket) about halfway up and a small nut near the top were key for me... A tricam might work in place pf the camalot...
content.location: Start right of the tree at the base of the steep part of the cliff...

content.description:
Maybe the most obvious route here... Fun climbing but its normally wet, and loose in spots...  

  Climb the deep corner to the right of the steep wall stemming most of the way and following a wide crack/groove to the top...
content.protection: Top rope recommened or bring a reguler rack and work with funk gear...
content.location: The deep corner to the right of the steep wall...

content.description:
On the far right locate a crack in the bulge above... Climb up to it and over the top to a crack in the slab... Climb moderate rock to the top... this line is longer and more fun than it looks... 

  There is some loose stuff on this one... If you lead it be careful where you place things as the loose rocks could shift and ruin your day...
content.protection: Regular rack maybe a fist sized piece for pulling the bulge...
content.location: The Far right hand route at the cliff... Look for the crack in the bulge..

content.description:
Short but sweet... Fun, interesting moves on solid rock...  

  From a ledge on the left side of the cliff step out right and climb the thin face holds and cracks up a short wall to the top at the trees...
content.protection: Small gear as i remember or a nice solid TR...
content.location: On the left side of the cliff there are ledges you can scramble up to... Climb up on to the left most ledge and climb up from the right side of the ledge...

content.description:
A really fun climb and one of the easiest to spot due to the crack at the base and one up high...Pretty well protected but a couple loose rocks getting in to it...  

  On the right side of the wall look for an obvious corner... Climb up a wide crack/flake to a stance below the corner... Pull out an overhang and in to the corner with a crack... Climb the corner to the top... Belay from trees...
content.location: On the right side of the steep face look for the wide crack and a fingercrack in a corner above...

content.description:
This is the best route under 5.8 at the cliff... 

  Very cool moves off the ground following the arete... you get a rest on a ledge after the crux beginning Pretty much contunue on the arete to the top staying left of the wide crack at the top of Fawkes...
content.location: The arete between the steep right side and low angle left side of the cliff... climb it...

content.description:
Cool steep climbing... Mega crimpy in the crux with cool fun moves the whole way... Recomended! 

  Climb up to the steep wall and get a piece in a crystal pocket... Micro crimp your way up then dyno (well above your gear) to a really good jug and some more gear... Climb up to a good rest and pull straight over one more bulge at 5.11ish... Belay from trees... Described for the lead but toprope recommended first unless you really rock...
content.protection: A yellow C3 camalot was helpful in the low crystal pocket then regular rack to the top...
content.location: Start on the left side of the tree at the base of the steep wall...

content.description:
The start is pretty much the same as Ginny's Secret but instead of climbing the easy groove you climb straight up the wall above... The rock is slick and the gear a little funky in spots but its safe and fun...  

  This was the first line we climbed when we discovered the cliff...

Yup... Its a harry potter theme, deal with it, haha...This hidden micro crag is located in the back woods of Goffstown NH... The existing routes were put up by Lee Hansche and Jakob Montoya starting in the spring of 2007... Others may have climbed here in the past but there was no sign of any activity... Developement was done without any bolts and it should stay that way... There are great trees for setting up top ropes and most of the routes put up so far have been led either ground up or in a headpoint style using sometimes tricky, suspect or wide spread trad gear.... A few of the moderate routes host pretty good gear placements...    Lots of loose rock was cleaned from the steeper routes and what is left for loose stuff is pretty well stuck... You should however be careful yarding on anything thats not super solid...    We have been unable to figure out who owns the land the cliffs are on so care should be taken not to upset land owners and respect should be the rule when meeting people in these woods... I don't climb here too often but i would be bummed if the cliff was closed to climbing since its literally 1 mile from my house...
